what: ezknitr - Avoid the typical working directory pain when using ‘knitr’
title: Package ezknitr
text: Copyright 2016 Dean Attali. Licensed MIT license. knitr popular package generating dynamic reports R using concept literate programming. ezknitr extension knitr adds flexibility several ways solves issues commonly encountered knitr. One common source frustration knitr assumes directory source file lives working directory, often true. ezknitr addresses problem giving complete control inputs outputs , adds several convenient features. two main functions ezknit() ezspin(), wrappers around knitr’s knit() spin(), used make rendering markdown/HTML documents easier.

previous_headings: ezknitr - Avoid the typical working directory pain when using ‘knitr’
title: Package ezknitr
text: Installation Overview Motivation & simple use case Use case: using one script analyze multiple datasets Experiment ezknitr spin() vs knit() Using rmarkdown::render() ezknitr available CRAN GitHub. install CRAN version: install latest developmental version GitHub: simple project flat directory structure, knitr works great. even something simple trying knit document reads file different directory placing output rendered files different folder easily done knitr. ezknitr improves basic knitr functionality ways. get decide: Default current working directory, often makes sense knitr assumption working directory wherever input file knitr, rendered output files generated folder ’re currently knitr makes cumbersome change directory Useful want run identical source file multiple times different parameters Assume Rmarkdown file reads data file produces short report also generating figure. Native knit() (spin() ’re starting R script instead Rmd file) works great flat directory structure like : happens slightly complex structure? real project, rarely everything just lying around folder. example realistic initial directory structure (assume working directory/project root set project/): Now want knitr work, ’d ensure path input.csv relative analysis/ directory ’s Rmd file . counter-intuitive people expect create paths relative working directory/project root (project/ case), knitr use analysis/ folder working directory. code reading input file needs use ../data/input.csv instead data/input.csv. confusing, also means naively run Rmd code chunks manually run code console, working directory set knitr use working directory. specifically, try run command reads input file, console look project/../data/input.csv (doesn’t exist). similar problem arises want create files report: knitr create files relative Rmd file , rather relative project root. Another problem flat directory structure may want control resulting reports get generated. knitr create outputs working directory, far know way control . ezknitr addresses issues, . provides wrappers knit() spin() allow set working directory input file, also uses sensible default working directory: current working directory. ezknitr also lets decide output files output figures generated, uses better default path output files: directory containing input file. Assuming working directory currently set project/ directory, use following ezknitr command want: didn’t explicitly set working direcory, can use wd argument require different directory (example, running build script arbitrary directory). running ezknit(), can run open_output_dir() open output directory file browser want easily see resulting report. Getting similar directory structure knitr simple, ezknitr ’s trivial. Note ezknitr produces markdown HTML file report (can choose discard keep_md keep_html arguments). example complex realistic scenario ezknitr useful, imagine multiple analysis scripts, one needing run multiple datasets. organizer scientist , want able run analysis dataset, keep results neatly organized. personally involved projects requiring exactly , ezknitr fact born solving exact issue. Assume following files project: can easily use ezknitr run analysis Rmarkdowns datasets assign results unique output. Let’s assume analysis script expects variable named DATASET_NAME inside script tells script data operate . following ezknitr code illustrates achieve desired output. Note example uses params = list() argument, lets pass variables input Rmarkdown. case, use tell Rmarkdown dataset use, Rmarkdown assumes DATASET_NAME variable exists. course means analysis script external dependency variable defined inside . can use set_default_params() function inside Rmarkdown ensure variable uses default value none provided. Also note differentiating species output also done using out_suffix argument instead out_dir argument. example, using out_suffix = "human" resulted ouput file named explore-human.md. installing loading package (library(ezknitr)), can experiment ezknitr using setup_ezknit_test() setup_ezspin_test() functions see benefits. See ?setup_ezknit_test information. knit() popular well-known function knitr. lets create markdown document Rmarkdown file. can learn knit() official knitr page. spin() similar, starts one step back: takes R script input, creates Rmarkdown document R script, proceeds create markdown document . spin() can useful situations develop large R script want able produce reports directly instead copy chunks separate Rmarkdown file. can read like spin() blog post “knitr’s best hidden gem: spin”. core package developed, none functionality supported way either knitr rmarkdown. time, rmarkdown::render() got new features similar features ezknitr. Native support parameters inside Rmarkdown files using YAML big feature makes use set_default_params() params argument ezknitr less important. However, core problem ezknitr wants solve working directory issue, issue yet addressed rmarkdown knitr, makes ezknitr still useful. Please note project released Contributor Code Conduct. participating project agree abide terms.
code: install.packages("ezknitr") install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("ropensci/ezknitr") - project/   |- input.csv   |- report.Rmd - project/   |- analysis/      |- report.Rmd   |- data/      |- input.csv library(ezknitr) ezknit(file = "analysis/report.Rmd", out_dir = "reports", fig_dir = "myfigs") - project/   |- analysis/      |- report.Rmd   |- data/      |- input.csv   |- reports/      |- myfigs/         |- fig1.png      |- report.md      |- report.HTML - project/   |- analysis/      |- calculate.Rmd      |- explore.Rmd   |- data/      |- human.dat      |- mouse.dat library(ezknitr) ezknit(file = "analysis/explore.Rmd", out_dir = "reports/human",         params = list("DATASET_NAME" = "human.dat"), keep_html = FALSE) ezknit(file = "analysis/explore.Rmd", out_dir = "reports/mouse",         params = list("DATASET_NAME" = "mouse.dat"), keep_html = FALSE) ezknit(file = "analysis/calculate.Rmd", out_dir = "reports/mouse",         params = list("DATASET_NAME" = "mouse.dat"), keep_html = FALSE) - project/   |- analysis/      |- calculate.Rmd      |- explore.Rmd   |- data/      |- human.dat      |- mouse.dat   |- reports/      |- human/         |- explore.md      |- mouse/         |- calculate.md         |- explore.md

what: ezknitr: Avoid the Typical Working Directory Pain When Using 'knitr' — ezknitr-package
title: ezknitr: Avoid the Typical Working Directory Pain When Using 'knitr' — ezknitr-package
text: extension 'knitr' adds flexibility several ways. One common source frustration 'knitr' assumes directory source file lives working directory, often true. 'ezknitr' addresses problem giving complete control inputs outputs , adds several convenient features make rendering markdown/HTML documents easier.

title: ezknitr: Avoid the Typical Working Directory Pain When Using 'knitr' — ezknitr-package
text: Maintainer: Dean Attali daattali@gmail.com

what: Knit Rmd or spin R files without the typical pain of working directories — ezknitr_core
title: Knit Rmd or spin R files without the typical pain of working directories — ezknitr_core
text: ezknitr extension knitr adds flexibility several ways. One common source frustration knitr assumes directory source file lives working directory, often true. ezknitr addresses problem giving complete control inputs outputs , adds several convenient features. two main functions ezknit  ezspin, wrappers around knitr's knit spin, used make rendering markdown/HTML documents easier.

title: Knit Rmd or spin R files without the typical pain of working directories — ezknitr_core
code: ezspin(   file,   wd,   out_dir,   fig_dir,   out_suffix,   params = list(),   verbose = FALSE,   chunk_opts = list(tidy = FALSE),   keep_rmd = FALSE,   keep_md = TRUE,   keep_html = TRUE,   move_intermediate_file = TRUE,   ... )  ezknit(   file,   wd,   out_dir,   fig_dir,   out_suffix,   params = list(),   verbose = FALSE,   chunk_opts = list(tidy = FALSE),   keep_md = TRUE,   keep_html = TRUE )

title: Knit Rmd or spin R files without the typical pain of working directories — ezknitr_core
text: file path input file (.Rmd file using ezknit  .R script using ezspin). wd provided, path  relative wd. wd working directory used Rmd/R script. Defaults current working directory (note behaviour knitr). See 'Detailed Arguments' section details. out_dir output directory rendered markdown HTML files (wd provided, path relative wd). Defaults directory containing input file. fig_dir name (path) directory figures generated. See 'Detailed Arguments' section details. out_suffix suffix add output files. Can used differentiate outputs runs different parameters. name output files name input file appended out_suffix, separated dash. params named list parameters passed use input Rmd/R file. example, script execute assumes variable named DATASET_NAME, can use params = list('DATASET_NAME' = 'oct10dat'). verbose TRUE, show progress knitting document. chunk_opts List knitr chunk options use. See  ?knitr::opts_chunk list available chunk options. keep_rmd, keep_md intermediate Rmd md files kept (TRUE) deleted (FALSE)? keep_html final html file kept (TRUE) deleted (FALSE)? move_intermediate_file intermediate Rmd file moved output folder (TRUE) stay folder source R file (FALSE)? ... extra parameters passed knitr::spin.

title: Knit Rmd or spin R files without the typical pain of working directories — ezknitr_core
text: path output directory (invisibly).

title: Knit Rmd or spin R files without the typical pain of working directories — ezknitr_core
text: simple project flat directory structure, knitr works great. even something simple trying knit  document reads file different directory placing output  rendered files different folder easily done knitr. ezknitr improves basic knitr functionality ways. get decide: working directory source file output files go figures used markdown go parameters pass source file

title: Knit Rmd or spin R files without the typical pain of working directories — ezknitr_core
text: paths given arguments can either absolute relative. wd argument important set current working directory default. path input file path output directory relative wd (unless absolute paths). Moreover, code R script reads writes files use wd working directory. fig_dir argument relative output directory, since figures accompanying markdown file placed directory. recommended either leave fig_dir default set different name different directory. way knitr works, known minor issues fig_dir set different directory.

title: Knit Rmd or spin R files without the typical pain of working directories — ezknitr_core
text: ezknit wrapper around knitr::knit ezspin wrapper around ezspin. two functions similar. knit popular well-known function. used  render markdown/HTML document Rmarkdown source.  spin takes R script input, produces Rmarkdown document R script, calls knit .

title: Knit Rmd or spin R files without the typical pain of working directories — ezknitr_core
code: if (FALSE) {    tmp <- setup_ezknit_test()    ezknit("R/ezknit_test.Rmd", wd = "ezknitr_test")    ezknit("R/ezknit_test.Rmd", wd = "ezknitr_test",           out_dir = "output", fig_dir = "coolplots",           params = list(numPoints = 50))    open_output_dir()    unlink(tmp, recursive = TRUE, force = TRUE)      tmp <- setup_ezspin_test()    ezspin("R/ezspin_test.R", wd = "ezknitr_test")    ezspin("R/ezspin_test.R", wd = "ezknitr_test",           out_dir = "output", fig_dir = "coolplots",           params = list(numPoints = 50), keep_rmd = TRUE)    open_output_dir()    unlink(tmp, recursive = TRUE, force = TRUE) }

what: Open the directory containing the output from the last ezknitr command — open_output_dir
title: Open the directory containing the output from the last ezknitr command — open_output_dir
text: Call function running ezspin ezknit open resulting output directory file browser. simply convenience function want see results need navigate appropriate folder manually.

title: Open the directory containing the output from the last ezknitr command — open_output_dir
Open the directory containing the output from the last ezknitr command — open_output_dir
code: if (FALSE) { library(ezknitr) setup_ezspin_test() ezspin("R/ezspin_test.R", wd = "ezknitr_test") open_output_dir() }

title: Set default parameters — set_default_params
text: Create variables given values variables currently exist.

title: Set default parameters — set_default_params
text: params List parameters.

title: Set default parameters — set_default_params
text: Sometimes may useful define variable defined yet. One example can useful Rmd script  uses variables want able use custom values variables, also give default value script case set beforehand.

title: Set default parameters — set_default_params
code: exists("foo") #> [1] FALSE exists("bar") #> [1] FALSE foo <- 5 set_default_params(list(foo = 10, bar = 20)) print(foo) #> [1] 5 print(bar) #> [1] 20

what: Set up a test directory to experiment with ezspin or ezknit — setup_ezspin_test
title: Set up a test directory to experiment with ezspin or ezknit — setup_ezspin_test
text: Create directories try mimic real data-analysis project structure, add data file simple R script (ezspin) Rmarkdown file (ezknit). setting files directories, can run ezknitr commands equivalent knitr commands compare see benefits using ezknitr. specific instructions interact test directory printed console.

title: Set up a test directory to experiment with ezspin or ezknit — setup_ezspin_test
Set up a test directory to experiment with ezspin or ezknit — setup_ezspin_test
text: path test directory.

title: Set up a test directory to experiment with ezspin or ezknit — setup_ezspin_test
code: if (FALSE) { library(ezknitr)  # setup the test directory structures and run naive spin setup_ezspin_test() knitr::spin("ezknitr_test/R/ezspin_test.R") file.remove(c("ezspin_test.md", "ezspin_test.html"))  # setup the test directory structures and run simple ezspin setup_ezspin_test() ezspin("R/ezspin_test.R", wd = "ezknitr_test")  # setup the test directory structures and run ezspin with more parameters tmp <- setup_ezspin_test() ezspin("R/ezspin_test.R", wd = "ezknitr_test",         out_dir = "output", fig_dir = "coolplots") unlink(tmp, recursive = TRUE, force = TRUE) }
